Thank you to our employees and our families for participating and trusting in our reopening process. #wearecolchester #reopeningschools #welcomeback 

If you'd like to share some of your photos of your first week of school, especially from our students that are learning virtually, feel free to post them in the comments!

post_text: An inside look at Superintendent Amy Minor's office as she and our team of six district nurses kicked off CSD's annual Opening In-service Ceremony this morning. Together, they led over 300 faculty and staff through a four hour interactive Zoom presentation going over the district reopening plan. We celebrated milestones work anniversaries, poured over the state's guidance and local decisions our district's administrators have made, did a deep dive into the layers of health and safety measures put in place and asked and answered lots of great questions. In between those segments, they got to see videos from students welcoming them back and shared their own excitement to once again have students in the classroom. It's going to be an unusual year for sure, but whether you're on the other side of a screen at home or the other side of a mask in school, it'll still be Colchester. Welcome back, teachers and staff! #wearecolchester

post_text: As part of their TA work with empathy, Team Sequoia over at the middle school worked with the nonprofit, Project Linus Chittenden, Lamoille, & Franklin Cos VT Chapter, to make blankets for the UVM Children's Hospital. Many of the supplies were donated by the organization, but to offset costs, families could make a monetary donation. Students worked in pairs to make close to 30 blankets to donate. While the donations are something to celebrate, the real cause for celebration is the empathy students expressed for others as they reflected on the project. One student shared how much he focused on the fact that the blanket would be going to a child in need. Another student shared that by doing the project she became more aware of the needs of others. After a discussion with classmates about a fellow student in our district who is struggling, they decided to provide a blanket to them as well! You can find out more about Project Linus on their website: www.projectlinus.org.

post_text: After earning the New England championship title in the mens 300m hurdles earlier this month, Colchester High School athlete, George Cummings 20 headed to North Carolina this past weekend to compete at Nationals. Cummings entered into his first ever 400m hurdles race and was placed in the Emerging Elite category where he took first place with a time of 53.55. Cummings said in an interview that he was nervous to run the 400m since in Vermont they train and compete at the 300m distance. He didnt know what that extra 100m would feel like but since he hopes to compete in college where 400m is the standard, he wanted to give it a try. Following his win, George headed straight back to Vermont to compete in the Vermont State Jerry Jasinski Decathlon Championship at UVM where he took 2nd overall with a personal best score of 5411. Congratulations, George! #wearecolchester #lakernation

A group of Colchester High School students took park in VSAC's Day at the Statehouse yesterday. All of the CHS students who attended are English Learner, or EL, students. Theyve moved to America from all over the world and are acclimating to American culture, education, and government. This trip gave them the opportunity to tour the capital, meet their local representatives, and experience first hand how government works by sitting in on several committees. The students were in awe by the detailed process committee members go through when working on bills.

Beni, one of our students, even had a special one-on-one meeting with Tim Ashe, the President pro tempore of the Vermont Senate. He and one of his teachers noticed that Mr. Ashe is a huge Barcelona fan, which also happens to be Benis favorite team. His teacher was able to help Beni get a message to Mr. Ashe, who agreed to meet him and talk all things soccer.

It doesnt matter where you're from, we all have things in common. #wearecolchester #ELstudents #everyoneiswelcomehere #educationforall

The Colchester School District will be conducting a routine test of our emergency notification system on Thursday, November 1 at 12:00 pm.

The district is committed to providing factual and timely information in the event of an emergency or school closure and uses a program called School Messenger to communicate with families simultaneously via phone, text, and email.

Most commonly, this system is used to announce a school closure in the event of poor weather conditions but it is also used to contact families in the event of a school-hours emergency.

If you would like to update or change your contact information in advance of this test or if you do not receive a call during the test and feel you should have, please contact the front office at the school your child attends to review your information.

The sale was organized through The Pulsera Project a Fair Trade nonprofit organization that empowers and educates people in the U.S. and Central America through pulsera sales.

Student and teacher volunteers are raising funds that benefit fair trade jobs, worker rights, sustainability, and education, while learning about the culture, lives, and struggles of Central Americans. The Pulsera Projects goal is to create a more just and colorful world by encouraging conscious consumerism and social enterprise.

The students at MBS are helping with The Great Diaper Drive of 2017. The goal is to collect as many diapers as possible to donate to COTS. Many families at the shelter don't have money for diapers and their children end up wearing soiled clothing. This often leads to numerous health issues.

This is the 10th year the wonderful folks over at Dee PT have hosted the drive and throughout the years they have been able to collect more than 210,000 diapers for struggling parents. They're looking to make this year the biggest!

MBS will be collecting diapers at the front office until December 13th. Please share this post and donate if you can!

Looking for a childcare option this school year? Pre-K at Malletts Bay School has one afternoon spot open!

The class follows the school year calendar and meets in half day sessions Tuesday-Friday from 12:00 pm - 2:45 pm. It is a qualified Community Partner Program which means parents can receive tuition funding up to $3,178!

Children in the program will practice language, social communication, and play skills. They will develop friendships while gaining confidence and school-readiness skills in a literacy-rich environment with experienced educators and support personnel.

The spot is open to any child who will be between the ages of 3 and 5 by August 31, 2017. Transportation is not provided.

Contact Nancy Smith at nancy.smith@colchestersd.org for more information.

Did you know that CSD is home to the Vermont State Ambassador for Fuel Up to Play 60? FUTP60 is a National student-run program, which focuses on school nutrition and physical activity to help encourage kids to lead healthier lives.

Our very own Cat Jones is the ambassador for Vermont! She is currently a CMS 8th grader who has been involved in the program since she was at MBS. She is raising money to attend the National Summit, which will be held next month in Minneapolis, MN. To help cover her admission costs, travel, food, lodging, training, and special events during the four-day summit she has started a Go Fund Me page.

Cat outlines all of the amazing things she's done for our district in the last four years (and all the things she plans to accomplish at CHS in the next four!) on her Go Fund Me page.

post_text: First-grade artists at UMS learned the power of repurposing materials in this strange and unlikely project. Each student picked one shoe from a large pile of unwanted footwear that was donated to the art program. The first task was to transform the shoe into a sculpture. On the second day they painted the shoes, and on the third day, they added embellishments. These young artists have shown us that art can be formed from anything, you just have to combine your imagination with a little creativity! You can check out this transformed footwear at the Burnham Memorial Library on Main Street.

post_text: Our very own Mrs. Mazza will be representing CSD at the annual Ronald McDonald Wait-A-Thon this year! It takes place a week from today, Monday, March 27th from 5:00 - 9:30 pm at Waterworks in Winooski. The wait-a-thon is a competition amongst our local celebrities as to how many tables they can serve and how much money they can make! All of the earned "tip" money benefits the Ronald McDonald House Charities. We're pulling for our very own Lynn Mazza to win! Call Waterworks now to reserve a table under her name. The more tables she has, the more tips she'll earn for a well deserving charity. (If you need more motivation to donate, the reigning champ is from South Burlington High School.....) #colchesterpride #teacherswhovolunteer #rmhc

As we make the final push to the polls, we have one last video to share with you from our Your Vote Matters series. We've titled this video "Be the Difference" because we believe at the end of the day, it could come down to just a handful of ballots. As timing would have it, Superintendent Minor gets to share some exciting news with you in this video. (Spoiler alert: the tax increase is going to be lower than we originally anticipated!)

We hope that if you haven't already, you'll come out to vote on the school budget tomorrow, Tuesday, March 7th, from 7 am to 7 pm at CHS.
